xml_element.name: job_chain
xml_element.title: Job chain
xml_element.author: $Author: aa $

description.p: The name of the job chain. Note that a job chain can only be defined once.
visible="no" and visible="never" make a job chain invisible in the results of and .
The JobScheduler makes a job chain visible as soon as an order has been added to the chain.

div.p: When the JobScheduler has been configured to store orders in the database, as soon as an order is added to a job's order queue it will be also be stored in the database. After the order has completed the job chain, it will be deleted from the database
The JobScheduler loads orders from the database on starting and setting up the job chains. See .
This attribute does not function when the JobScheduler has been configured to work without a database - see .

description.p: The JobScheduler does not store orders in or load orders from a database.
See Database.
Only works when specified in conjunction with and causes orders to be distributed over more than one JobScheduler.

distributed="no" prevents a job chain from being processed by more than one JobScheduler. Instead, causes a job chain to be processed on the one JobScheduler, as if it were in a non-distributed environment. Note that in this situation, the name of the job chain must be unique in the cluster (Note that this is not checked by the JobScheduler).
A job chain can also be given a title.
See also .

In general an unlimited number of orders for a job_chain could ran simultaneously. To declare the attribute max_orders it is possible to limit this number. E.g. max_orders='1' let run the job_chain exclusively for one order. A new order for this job_chain can only run, if the first order was finished.
The number of simultaneous orders for a job_chain is not limited, if this attribute is not set.

p.b: This attribute will take only effect if the order starts with the first node of the job chain.

description.p: A can be used to to specify the default Agent or Remote JobScheduler to be used for processing the job chain.
See How to execute Jobs and Job Chains with Agents for more information.

example.pre: <process_classes> <process_class max_processes="10" remote_scheduler="http://MY-SERVER:4445" name="agent-1" /> </process_classes> <job_chains> <job_chain title="Job Chain 1" process_class="agent-1" name="job_chain_1"> <job_chain_node state="1" job="job_1" next_state="2" error_state="error" /> <job_chain_node state="2" job="job_2" next_state="success" error_state="error" /> <job_chain_node state="success" /> <job_chain_node state="error" /> </job_chain> </job_chains>

description.p: A can be used to to specify an Agent that is to be used to watch for files arriving at the Agent host. This Agent triggers file orders for incoming files.
This process class is used to define both the and elements.
If the file_watching_process_class attribute is empty, it defaults to the process class of the job chain.
The process class must denote only one agent.
Changing the process class at runtime will have no effect on the file_order_source or file_order_sink.

When the process contains both the remote_scheduler attribute and the remote_schedulers element, the remote_schedulers element will be ignored when the process class is used for the file_watching_process_class attribute or file_watching_process_class in the element.
See the JobScheduler Universal Agent - Remote File Watching article for more information.

example.pre: <process_classes> <process_class max_processes="10" remote_scheduler="http://MY-SERVER:4445" name="agent-1" /> </process_classes> <job_chains> <job_chain title="Job Chain 1" process_class="agent-1" file_watching_process_class"agent-2" name="job_chain_1"> <file_order_source directory="/tmp/jobscheduler/file/incoming/agent_file_watching" regex=".*" /> <job_chain_node state="1" job="job_1" next_state="2" error_state="error" /> <job_chain_node state="2" job="job_2" next_state="success" error_state="error" /> <job_chain_node state="success" /> <job_chain_node state="error" /> </job_chain> </job_chains>

description.h3: Superordinate Job Chains - a Chain of Job Chains
description.p: Superordinate job chains refer to other job chains and are described using the . XML elements. A superordinate job chain can only contain simple job chains.
Superordinate job chains cannot be used in combination with distributed orders.

xml_element.example:
<job_chains>
    <job_chain name="Chain_A">
        <job_chain_node state=  "1" job="job_a" next_state=  "2" error_state="999" />            
        <job_chain_node state=  "2" job="job_b" next_state="100" error_state="999" />            
        <job_chain_node state="100" />
        <job_chain_node state="999" />
    </job_chain>
</job_chains>

This is the same as the following JobScheduler script:

<script language="javascript"><![CDATA[
    var job_chain = spooler.create_job_chain();
        job_chain.name = "Chain_A";
        job_chain.add_job( "job_a", 1,   2, 999 );
        job_chain.add_job( "job_b", 2, 100, 999 );
        job_chain.add_end_state( 100 );
        job_chain.add_end_state( 999 );
    spooler.add_job_chain( job_chain );
]]></script>
